docs.snippet: Garcia (1874-1949) recurs like a predictable, if not very fiery, comet. This time, it may be viewed in an unusually well- composed show at the elegant new Herstand Gallery, 24 West 57th Street. The display, smaller than one held at Salander O'Reilly...
docs.lead_paragraph: Garcia (1874-1949) recurs like a predictable, if not very fiery, comet. This time, it may be viewed in an unusually well- composed show at the elegant new Herstand Gallery, 24 West 57th Street. The display, smaller than one held at Salander O'Reilly in 1981, numbers about 15 canvases dated 1938-48 and a few wood constructions of 1929-30. Maybe the best way of approaching this artist is by way of regular installments, since his life didn't exactly progress in linear fashion, but like his imagery, arranged itself in compartments. In the first of these, were 17 years he spent in his native Uruguay, evidently growing up an autodidact; the second was the Spanish period, when after having studied briefly in Barcelona, the artist worked as an assistant to the architect Antonio Gaudi, eventually becoming a muralist. Except for trips to Belgium and Italy, Torres-Garcia remained in Spain for almost 30 years, then took off for New York by way of Paris. Despite a friendly reception and a show at the Whitney Studio Club, the artist was not too happy in this country and after two years went back to France, remaining until 1932, when he went to Spain and, finally, to Montevideo.

headline.main: ART: 15 LATER WORKS IN TORRES-GARCIA SHOW

docs.snippet: Raul Ricardo Alfonsin was inaugurated President of Argentina today amid joyous celebrations that ended nearly eight years of military rule.     More than 100,000 Argentines poured into the streets to cheer the 56-year-old political moderate as a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Raul Ricardo Alfonsin was inaugurated President of Argentina today amid joyous celebrations that ended nearly eight years of military rule. More than 100,000 Argentines poured into the streets to cheer the 56-year-old political moderate as a sense of hope gripped this long-tumultuous country. Waving flags and wearing white berets, a symbol of Mr. Alfonsin's Radical Party, the crowds rained confetti on him as he traveled in a 1950's Cadillac convertible from the swearing in at the Congress to the Pink House, the presidential palace. Columns of cavalry marched by his side.

headline.main: ARGENTINE LEADER SWORN INTO OFFICE, ENDING ARMY RULE

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: WHEN Carmen Popescu stepped into the bright August sunlight beyond her prison last summer in Bucharest, Rumania, guards handed her a food package from Dobbs Ferry.    The release of Mrs. Popescu, who had been jailed in 1981 for ''propaganda against...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Carmen Popescu stepped into the bright August sunlight beyond her prison last summer in Bucharest, Rumania, guards handed her a food package from Dobbs Ferry. The release of Mrs. Popescu, who had been jailed in 1981 for ''propaganda against the socialist state,'' had been the goal of Amnesty International Adoption Group No. 253, Hastings-Dobbs Ferry Chapter. The Amnesty International organization and its local chapters never claim credit for the release of a prisoner, although vigorous efforts may have been made in the process. The 15 teachers, homemakers and business executives in Adoption Group 253 wrote more than 100 letters to Rumanian officials, Congressional Representatives, State Department officials and to the press on Carmen Popescu's behalf. They sent food parcels at their own expense. Last spring, they held a vigil near the Rumanian Mission to the United Nations in New York City and accounts of the vigil were broadcast by Radio Free Europe.

headline.main: FOUR AMNESTY GRUPS ACTIVE IN COUNTY

docs.snippet: When Wilson Ferreyra Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan opposition leader, came here as a specially invited guest for the inauguration Saturday of President Raul Alfonsin, he was interviewed by a leading Uruguayan newspaper.   The interview, in which he...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Wilson Ferreyra Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan opposition leader, came here as a specially invited guest for the inauguration Saturday of President Raul Alfonsin, he was interviewed by a leading Uruguayan newspaper. The interview, in which he extolled democracy and asked for respect from the military rulers in his own country to allow him to return home, was published Sunday inconspicuously on page 4 of the newspaper, El Dia. Today, the Uruguayan military issued a decree closing the newspaper for three days. The interview, the decree said, was with someone who has ''no national rights.''

docs.snippet: Uruguay's military rulers announced a partial shuffle of the Cabinet today in advance of elections promised for November 1984.
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay's military rulers announced a partial shuffle of the Cabinet today in advance of elections promised for November 1984.

headline.main: New Cabinet Ministers Appointed in Uruguay

docs.snippet: Christian Democrats from 15 countries sponsored a major rally here Monday night and called on Chile's military rulers to move toward democracy.   Andres Zaldivar, president of the Christian Democratic International, told the meeting of 5,000 people...
docs.lead_paragraph: Christian Democrats from 15 countries sponsored a major rally here Monday night and called on Chile's military rulers to move toward democracy. Andres Zaldivar, president of the Christian Democratic International, told the meeting of 5,000 people that military governments in Latin America had been disastrous.

headline.main: Christian Democrats Of World Rally in Chile

docs.snippet: President Raul Alfonsin's surprise announcement Tuesday that he would prosecute former military leaders drew widely favorable reaction among Argentines today. Military officials had no immediate comment.   Adam Pedrini, head of the opposition...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Raul Alfonsin's surprise announcement Tuesday that he would prosecute former military leaders drew widely favorable reaction among Argentines today. Military officials had no immediate comment. Adam Pedrini, head of the opposition Peronist party in the Chamber of Deputies, called the move to prosecute the nine generals and admirals who at different times made up the ruling junta between 1976 and 1982 ''excellent.''

headline.main: ARGENTINES HAIL PLAN TO PROSECUTE JUNTA LEADERS

docs.snippet: For eight years, generals and admirals terrorized Argentina with their lawless rule. Now, along with the civilian terrorists who provoked the repression, they are to be legally held to account. Argentina's newly elected President, Raul Alfonsin, is...
docs.lead_paragraph: For eight years, generals and admirals terrorized Argentina with their lawless rule. Now, along with the civilian terrorists who provoked the repression, they are to be legally held to account. Argentina's newly elected President, Raul Alfonsin, is off to a brave and bold start.

docs.snippet: Riot troops and mounted policemen charged into a crowd demonstrating against Uruguay's 10- year-old military Government on Thursday night and arrested about 100 people, witnesses said.   Several demonstrators were kicked, punched and hit with riot...
docs.lead_paragraph: Riot troops and mounted policemen charged into a crowd demonstrating against Uruguay's 10- year-old military Government on Thursday night and arrested about 100 people, witnesses said. Several demonstrators were kicked, punched and hit with riot sticks, they said.

headline.main: 100 Seized in Uruguay After Soldiers Charge
